review:
As of this writing, the price direct from Dell is much lower than at Amazon, especially if you opt for Dell's financing. A fully functional windows 8.1 15.6" laptop costing in the low $200s is mind blowing. Part of the $ savings derives from the lack of an optical drive or touch screen.

There isn't much to say. I've had it for about 2 weeks, so I can't judge durability. The laptop is made from cheap plastic, but the screen is nice, the keyboard feels sturdy and comfortable, you have a full numeric keypad. The only negative is the trackpad, which is usable but not good. We prefer to use a mouse instead.

We only use it for basics, like web browsing, Office, printing, sending email. It's certainly fast enough for all that. It connects to the wifi network quickly, and web browsing is fine.

I bought it from Dell and it came with a 1year home repair warranty. Really this is an outstanding value, if your computing needs are light.

Update:

I've had it 4 months. It runs the same as the day we got it.

FYI, it doesn't come with recovery disks, but there is a built-in utility to burn your own disks. Since the pc doesn't have an optical drive, you'll need an external drive to burn them.

I bought this laptop to replace a 10 year old laptop I had been using only to surf the web, email and watch a few videos. Nothing too extremely complex. Between the crashing, dropping wifi and slow uploads, this laptop is a piece of crap.

This is no I7 laptop, let's just get that straight.  But, it makes a good second back up laptop for me.  I'm using it to write this review right now.  I ordered mine from dell, at the time it was cheaper than amazon, and dell had them in stock.  I did remove the hard drive and replaced it with an SSD I had laying around which helped speed it up considerably.  It is a bit laggy at times, but overall it is usable and better than I would have expected for this price range.

Here are the pros as I see them:
-The price, the price, the price
-The weight is much lighter than my I7 high end laptop
-Battery lasts 5-7.5 hours depending on use, many Windows laptops in this price range only last 3 hours so this is a huge advantage.
-The battery is user replaceable, which you can't take for granted anymore in a laptop.  Press two buttons and it pops right out!
-Many laptops recently make it very hard to get access to the RAM and Harddrive for upgrades.  Several dells require you to completely disassemble the entire laptop to get to the hard drive including removing the screen, motherboard, track pad etc.  Which is a huge pet peave of mine.  This laptop has an access panel on the bottom to access the RAM and HD which is great!
-A large 15.6 inch screen for a great price
-This CPU doesn't run hot at all and has decent performance for the price.
-It runs so cool it doesn't even have a fan at all!
-Keyboard has a number pad, many don't in this price range.
-Keyboard feels nice and doesn't feel too cheap, we will see with time though how it holds up.
-Trackpad works good, buttons are loud when clicked though.
-Nice to have a Windows laptop for this price, I like chromebooks but I can't connect to my at home Samba server from a chromebook so I gravitate to Windows.

Cons:
-There are the obvious ones like no USB 3, no Bluetooth, no wired ethernet, no CD/DVD Drive.  But in this price range I'm ok with that.  I have an external USB CD/DVD that I used to install Office on it so that wasn't an issue for me.
-Windows 8.1, is better than 8.0 but if you have never used it before there is a learning curve for sure compared to Windows 7/Vista
-Not blazing fast but you can't expect that from any pc in this price range.
-Case feels cheap, it creaks and groans when I pick it up by a corner.
-The quality of the video is pretty low, but once again it is usable for watching youtube, netflix videos, etc.  Just is less sharp than my high end laptop and can be a tad laggy occasionally.

Would I recommend this???  Depends on your needs.  If you are on a tight budget and are a light PC user who wants to use it just for basic web surfing, Word Processing, and light youtube/netflix watching this will work fine for most people

If you are a high end, heavy user, I'd only use this as a backup laptop.  I would not be happy with this as my primary laptop personally since I'm a very heavy user.

If you are a gamer, you of course know enough to not even look at this laptop as an option.

Upgrade possibilities:  If you know what you are doing upgrading the hard drive to an SSD will help it feel more useable.  Also, I have not done so yet, but my understanding is that you can upgrade this to 8GB of ram which could help too.  It only has one slot for ram so you will have to remove the stock 4gb and replace it with an 8GB.  Make sure to get the DDR3L (The L stands for low voltage).  You want the 1.35 volt not 1.5 it may work with the 1.5 but will run hotter and use more battery.  The laptop comes with 1333mhz ram, but I think 1600mhz will work and run faster.  Take this with a grain of salt as have not tried it yet, but I believe the following RAM will work, and this is the type I plan to try upgrading to someday.

http://www.amazon.com/Kingston-Technology-1600MHz-PC3-12800-KVR16LS11/dp/B00CQ35HBQ/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1402328644&sr=8-2&keywords=8GB+DDR3+1600MHz+sodimm+DDR3L

Update 6/23/14: I did buy and install the 8gb of Ram above.  It works great, but it does down clock the ram to 1333mhz as the CPU won't handle 1600mhz speeds.  But, the 1600mhz 1.35v ram does work great in here.  It feels even snappier now.  Between the SSD I installed and the 8gb of ram this computer is very usable and fairly snappy for most tasks.  The only time I see the video and cpu lagging a bit is if I am on a webpage with heavy adobe flash usage on it.  But, right now I have two browsers open and about 30 browser tabs open with now slowdown.  I'm still quite happy with this laptop for the money.  It is just important to throttle your expectations, this can't be compared to an Intel I7 CPU $1000 laptop, but it is good for basic web browsing!

Update 8/22/14 I noticed several people that complained about the performance realized if they removed the demo anti virus and crapware that it runs better.  I reinstalled windows from scratch from my USB DVD when I put in the SSD so I effectively removed all of the crapware by reinstalling and only putting the essential drivers back on.  That is probably why mine runs much faster and better than some of the reviewers.  I would remove the anti virus and just use the built in windows 8.1 antivirus as that is less cpu and memory intensive.  Then uninstall of the other factory junk, like wild tangent games, toolbars etc.  If you don't want to do that manually in the past I used a free utility called PC Decrapifier that automated the cleanup and worked pretty good.  Also, you might need to change your power saving settings to be less restrictive so it is optimized more for speed.  Hope that helps...

I bought this Dell back when it was on sale. It was a smart purchase!

There are many positives with this machine:

1. It's not heavy like other laptops with this screen size.

2. The processor coupled with the four gigs of ram makes the overall speed of the machine pretty decent for everyday tasks.

3. The battery life is decent.

4. Dell technical support did stand by their product after an issue developed with the stock internal hard drive. after contacting them, they immediately sent me a new hard drive under warranty. Installation was quite straight forward and although I've done this to many laptops over the years, it would be quite easy for a novice to do!

5. The internal speakers are not bad! They have a bit more bass and volume than speakers on many smaller laptops.

6. The keyboard is really comfortable to type on and it has the number pad! My biggest gripe with many laptops is that the keyboard is cramped but not so with this machine!

And yes, there are some negatives:

1. I would highly suggest swapping the stock hard drive for an ssd. The machine will be a lot more reliable as you won't need to worry about a rotating mechanical hd and the various issues that can come with one of those in a laptop computer.

2. Windows 8/8.1 was and is a total dud. That being said, you can upgrade to Win 10 so that's not a big deal at this point.

3. The case of the machine can dent and scratch easily. That being said, the machine does not feel flimsy and we've had no issues due to the design of this case.

 All in all, yes, I'd recommend this machine for general computing and lite entertainment.

This review is for the Dell Inspiron 13531-1200BK 16-inch Laptop

Note: This is *not* a reflection on a particular seller - but the actual laptop itself.

I purchased this just over one year ago. And granted, this is a low-end laptop/notebook, so I wasn't expecting much. I knew it was a stripped-down, bare bones good for email and web surfing sort of setup. However, I wasn't thrilled with it when I got it, largely because Windows 8.1 is a horrible beast of an OS, and the computer lagged more than I was used to when doing even the simplest things. It also seemed cheaply constructed - moreso than any other Dell laptop I've ever purchased. The screen quality was meh, there's no bluetooth or DVD drive - granted, I knew about the DVD drive when I purchased it, but I really wasn't expecting it not to have bluetooth.

The real killer for me was that the hard drive and motherboard completely crashed one month after the warranty expired, and the cost quoted to repair it was actually close to the price I paid for the computer. To get back the data I lost? Almost a grand. I did back up most everything critical, but frankly I lost a lot.

So a year later, I have found myself in the position of having to buy an all new PC. Believe it or not, I did buy another Dell because I have always had good luck with them. But I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.

The customer support isn't bad and there are things that are very good about the computer. The problem is that those good features are only good during very specific circumstances. In the mean time when i use my computer every day the touch pad is nothing but trouble. it keeps causing me to alt tab when I don't want to or randomly turns off. There are no usb ports on the right side so if you like to have a wired mouse i hope your left handed or your cord is long. There is no ethernet input so if you don't have access to a good internet router the internet will be clunky. Its cheap it, gets the job done but there are some very simple design changes that could save a person a ton of hassle in their daily use of the product.

its not good but its also not considerably bad. I got this last Christmas and less than a year later it started to fall apart. I used for all purposes. Gaming, work, videos, streaming and if you go to the Dell website it even says that Inspirons could be used for all purposes, and it was working fine... for the first few months. After about 3 months of using it it started going considerably slow both in internet and other performance speed. there was also a panel on the bottom of the laptop that kept snapping out and i'm not kidding when I say I literally had to snap the panel back in. If that wasn't bad enough it would start to just turn off by itself both if left idle or I was actually doing something. I just shrugged this off as the computer just going slow because it was aging (even though it had only been a few months) I kept using it the way I was. About 7 months of having owned the computer the audio would just randomly cut off and no matter what I did i couldn't get it to come back on unless I completely shut down the computer, not even a restart would work. Now lets get onto the hardware of the laptop. Its very low on features all you get is a charging port, an HDMI port and two USB ports (which i also had problems with but I will get to later in this review). There is NO Ethernet port whatsoever and no microphone port either. Though these two components aren't required they're VERY useful to have and it's not as if without them the laptop will run faster it IS thick enough to put one on. Also there are only two USB ports? Most laptops have around three. Speaking of the USB ports THEY ENDING BREAKING OFF THE LAPTOP THEMSELVES. I was just using mouse one day and I take the mouse out and I pick up the laptop to take it to another room and and I hear  a faint little noise as if something fell onto the floor and i look around an find this little plastic USB part that is supposed to read what is inside the port just fell out the laptop. I tried to call Dell and see if there was anything I could do to fix it but the representative said that it was a "wear and tear problem" even though there is a one year warranty if bought new (which is how i bought it) and half the time of the call i'm pretty sure he didn't even know what he was talking about. He also said that to fix it, it was going to cost around $295 which at the time I bought it was more than what I paid for it, so I may as well have just bought a new one (as if i'm ever buying from Dell again). This is a great buy for the amount of money that I spent.  The only thing that it lacks in my opinion is Bluetooth.  But, it is not a deal breaker for me.  If you are a gamer, this is not the laptop for you, but if you were a gamer, you would already know that this is not the laptop for you.  If you are a student, working from home (in a non-technical field), browsing online, reading online, listening to music - this is the laptop for you!  I didn't purchase a warranty or anything and it has been going strong now for about a year.  The laptop is so quiet that I forget if it is on when it is in sleep mode.  The battery life is AMAZING!  It lasts for such a long time.  It would be perfect if it were not for the lack of Bluetooth, but you can still use the cord ones.  It has USB, a webcam, it has 10-key (which is a plus and kind of a deal breaker for me at this time), the mouse pad is user friendly and it just feels comfortable to me.  I have streamed Netflix (my internet speed is great though), and the picture quality is awesome. The search field on the front screen makes it easy to find anything that you are looking for within the computer itself.  It has a matte finish and not a shiny or slippery finish and it handles well. Like it a lot--best of all it has Windows 7--can't stand Window 8 and thereafter.  It's a big computer; it stays home.  For the price it is top-notch. The sound is not back and loud enough for my purposes.  The DVD player is a bit flimsy but it has not failed and does the job.  After MS Vista you cannot buy to own MS Office apps: you RENT or buy the annual license to used MS Word/Office.  You'll be paying every year.  This is crap--one reason I am keeping my older laptops just so I don't have to keep buying the right to use Office Word or Excell or Access!!!  Anyone who uses the Cloud storage for important document is crazy--it's not your document if it's in some one else's home, is it!  Keep you own external storage drivers.  I would only keep downloaded music in any 'floating' storage facility--I wouldn't even keep pictures in any fluff storage.  The picture is sharp, color is true, but the screen is much wider than I'm used to: because of the thinner bezel you have more viewing screen--nothing is wrong with this; I just have to get used to it.  Not that crazy about the clear glossy screen; it does reflects too much back image but it does give the picture clear and truer color display; really great watching movies in the dark.  I'll be using this for the Internet and saving my older laptop for work.  For a couple of hundred bucks, this laptop is a great value.  Would have given it 5 stars if it the keyboard was backlit.

Out of the box, I couldn't adjust the screen's brightness. Not too big a deal because installing the latest graphics driver off of Dell's website fixed the problem. At about the same time I discovered that the wireless card in this laptop (Dell Wireless 1506) is a piece of garbage. If you look at the top review for that wireless card here on Amazon, it talks about how with 802.11n you have to be sitting next to the router to get a good signal, which precisely describes my experience. Right now, I'm dealing with the fact that the display hurts my eyes.

The one bright side is that this computer isn't as slow as people make it out to be. I'm guessing the slowness that most people are experiencing is from the effects of the crappy wireless card.

So, yeah, this is the last time I buy a cheap laptop. Even if I overcome my current issue with this computer, it's been a hassle just to get this computer to run like it should out of the box.

Edit: Bumping to from 2 to 3 stars. Turns out the screen is easier on the eyes after being in use for a while. I had a eye strain issue with a desktop I bought later on. I still think the wifi card is garb.

Disclaimer: My review is based on the add-ons I installed when I got the laptop. I strongly suggest if you're looking at this laptop, that you set aside some extra money for the Upgrades I mention.

I first installed an SSD and a memory upgrade before I powered it on. I didn't even boot into Windows before installing Arch Linux, so I have only seen this laptop as a fast, lightweight, capable, everyday machine.

The memory upgrade I bought:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008LTBLLY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
The SSD I bought:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OAJ5N6I/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Now for the review. I really love this machine. My old laptop was a 6 and 1/2 year old gaming laptop that was finally on it's last legs. I needed something lighter and a bit simpler since I have another PC for gaming. After some research, this PC fit the bill. It's absolutely silent and is fairly cool for having no fans. While many reviews have said that this PC is dirt slow, I have to disagree. However, I installed Arch Linux on this PC right away, and it's made this Laptop the fastest PC in my house. To compare, my desktop has an i7, Xubuntu and 32GB of RAM. While I don't suggest newbies install Arch, I think that this PC should have shipped with Linux or should be installed to really appreciate how fast it is.

I also wanted to answer a few questions I had about this machine.

First, and most asked. No DVD/BD Drive. It has a Drive slot that I was planning on installing a caddy and second hard drive to, but the slot does not have a SATA connector. So, that means this PC will only ever have one Hard Drive and you cannot install a DVD/BD Drive inside.

It also has no Ethernet Port, not a dealbreaker, but sysadmins looking at this, may want a laptop with one.
Only 2 USB Ports, which is really only one if you need either a Ethernet connector or Optical drive.

When that one gave out she tasked me with finding her a more suitable basic computer. This product turned out to be a great fit. Not the fastest, but works extremely well and is of very high quality for the price. It is a sturdy machine that should last for a lot longer than the last one. If you are not very advanced with computers and only use your computer for basic tasks like browsing the web or word processing this product will exceed your expectations. If you are a little more advanced and/or demanding in your usage this product should still deliver, especially if you have a tight budget. I've had this laptop for about two weeks now, and so far I've really enjoyed using it. I've used it for some light gaming (FF7, Papers Please, Minecraft) and it runs fine. I also use it to listen to music and watch videos, which it does pretty well. Getting used to windows 8.1 is kind of difficult, since I'm coming from a machine running vista, but that's not a problem specific to this laptop, so I can't use that against it.

The keyboard takes some getting use to, but it's not too bad. It could definitely be more responsive though. The track pad and buttons are fine, pretty standard.

The screen is okay, I've found it's a bit bright for me, so I've been trying to find a good balance with it. I also use f.lux to dim the screen in the evening, which usually helps some. I am still trying to find the sweet spot though.

Overall I would say that if you're looking for a cheap budget laptop that can be used for music, videos, browsing and light gaming, this is a good buy.

However, if you're looking for a laptop that has the quality of a $2,000 MacBook Pro, then this isn't for you, obviously. If you want $2,000 specs, expect to pay $2,000 instead of leaving a 1 star because you couldn't be bothered to read the product description, or had ridiculous expectations.

I haven't used windows since XP but I wanted to run Quicken and the Mac version did not do what  I needed it to do. So I bought this PC mainly for Quicken. Price was great, there was a numeric keyboard, and it seemed like it would be more than adequate.

Turned it on, set it up, checked for windows updates, got rid of McAfee and put on Avast free, got rid of Internet Explorer and put on Chrome, installed Quicken program, ok. But I noticed that the text on websites was hard to read. Seemed sort of gray. Brightness did not help. Went into display settings, tried to adjust resolution, not possible. Tried to calibrate, received an error message for my trouble. Went to google to ask why I couldn't calibrate, came up with a generic solution to download latest drivers. Went to Dell support site, let it do a system analysis, and voila, there were 13 "recommended" drivers, updates, and downloads to perform, almost all requiring a restart. Including the graphics drivers. There was even a bios update, which I downloaded, performed the analysis, and the result was... the new version after flash would be exactly the same as before the flash.

There was no way to just "download all" so I clicked download for each individually. The notes under the file name said "This file will automatically self-install after downloading" but that did not happen. I had to go to the downloads folder and click each .exe file individually.
After the installs, and the restart, I found I now had the Intel HD Graphics Control Panel, which made it possible to calibrate, and adjust the display properties.

In short, the out of box experience left a lot to be desired. I would have thought that one would be able to turn on the computer for the first time and find everything that should be installed by the vendor, would be installed. Updates, ok, but at least install the programs. Lest I be accused of being a Mac fanboy, I easily set up my family's two Acer computers without having to search the Acer website to download drivers and updates just to make the PC function normally.

I like this computer so far, but I think it's asking a lot of the user to have to figure out that he first needs to go to Dell to download and install drivers and updates, restart, just to get the thing to function normally.

Windows 8.1 (OS on this laptop):
I really dislike windows 8.1.  I knew it came with 8.1 and I know the general consensus is that it was basically made for a touch screen.  I still wanted to try win 8.1 and I am deeply disappointed for many reasons.  One small reason is that there seems to be no other choice for scrolling than the "two finger scroll" or a mouse wheel.  The problem with two finger scroll is that if both fingers do not touch the touchpad at *exactly* the same time then it is interpreted as a single click.  So you are scrolling along and BAM you just clicked on something and off you go.  There is no driver that I could find for this touchpad that would allow me to "one finger scroll" aka "edge scroll" aka "linear scroll".  This is NOT the same as the "edge swipe" option that you will find in the touchpad options, that has nothing to do with scrolling.

I did install "Classic Shell" which gives it a much more Windows 7 feel (just google it or use your search engine of choice)

First of all, as many have said, this is not an I7 nor is it an I3 laptop. I own a Dell laptop with an I3 processor and it works well and of course is faster than this one running at 1.9 ghz. However, I bought this computer for my wife who is not into a lot of hard-core usage. Mainly light browsing, light gaming and emailing along with social networking. For those purposes, you'll be just fine. Please also understand that some modifications have to be made to the laptop as earlier reviewers have stated in reference to better performance. Remove all Dell bloatware including backup and recovery, digital delivery. You'll probably never use them, being that this features are built into the core OS. As far as the mouse goes, my wife and I are exclusively power users. I already knew that no CD drive nor ethernet port was present, but I was fine with that. My wife loves it.

I went in for a cheap laptop this time because money is tight.  I wasn't expecting much given the price but am a little surprised that Dell put out a product of such poor quality.

The laptop runs very slow at times and it can get really aggravating.  Internet Explorer crashes and reloads constantly.  Made of cheap plastic, including very loud-clicking mouse buttons that annoyed my roommates in the first twenty minutes of use.  Then there's Windows 8.1 which I personally consider inferior to its predecessors.

Let's discuss FastAccess.  Comes includes with the computer.  Uses the laptop's built-in camera to recognize your face any time you want to log into Windows or any website or program within Windows without having to enter a password.  I liked this concept at first but am ticked off about the execution.  First of all, if you intend to use the program much, it consumes a lot of the laptop's already limited RAM, substantially degrading performance.  Second, the light to my camera went on and off constantly, even when I wasn't trying to log into Windows or an Internet website.  When I tried using the computer's built in picture-taking "app" (the word they use now instead of "program"), I was not allowed to do so, apparently because of FastAccess.  That is to say, I thought I had uninstalled it successfully but found out later that the program had basically re-installed itself on my computer without even asking my permission.  In summary, the only reason I don't think I have this invasive malware product called FastAccess installed on my computer is because Dell chose to package it with the laptop.

On the plus side, the computer is able to run older generation PC games like Civ 3 without any trouble.  I'm not sure why it can do that but Internet Explorer has a seizure when I try running four or five tabs at the same time.  Also on the plus side, Microsoft gives you something called OneDrive which is a free cloud storage tool that automatically syncs to the Office products you use on your computer.  This is an awesome, integrated, multi-platform experience that is seamless and of course unbelievably convenient.  Apart from the cost of the Office products themselves, this OneDrive thing comes free with the computer.  A final plus is that it seems easy to download apps although I so far have not explored this option much as quite frankly I don't enjoy being on this laptop.

I don't like to grumble but I have buyer's remorse about this product.  I realize in retrospect I made the purchase based in large part on my respect for Dell's name; I simply did not expect a world class company like Dell to put out a product like this.  I just don't get what the designers' thought process was regarding this computer.  I do have a functioning laptop and this isn't the worst thing that could happen but the disappointment does stick.

So I can plug in my mouse and my external hard-drive and anytime I want to hook up my iPod, stick flashdrive, or webcam, I have to unplug something. The software runs fast, but it can't handle programs like photoshop, a wacom tablet, or video editing programs. Basically anything heavy-duty is going to crash.

The biggest issue I have had with this laptop is connecting to the internet. I have only had the laptop for a little over 2 months and it has already had several instances in which it could not connect. At one point it even said that it was connected but then any program that needed internet access to run crashed. All my other devices were connected just fine but the Dell Inspiron is NOTORIOUS for having issues with internet connectivity. Just google "dell Inspiron 15 won't connect to the internet" and you will see others are having the same problems.

Overall it runs fast, but I feel very limited to what I can do with this laptop. As a student who only works part-time, I needed something I could afford. Unfortunately, I also needed something that could keep up with my projects at school which require a more hardcore laptop I guess. Oh well, it's great for just ordinary home stuff like writing documents and browsing facebook. Battery life lasts about 4 hours.

I managed to get this for the "perfect storm" price of $179.99.  As usual, timing is everything when buying from Amazon.  I have only used it for a few hours, but so far it meets most of my needs.  The Celeron processor/RAM does show some limitations, such as I was playing a movie using the usually excellent VLC program and  the playback was stuttering and choppy.  Terrible.  I switched to another video program and it was fine.  It reminds me of taking a small 250CC motorcycle on the freeway when you are used to driving a sports car--yes, it will still work, but it is slower and you have to know your limits. For web surfing and word processing, it is totally adequate.  There are some other computers in the price range...HP Stream 11, for example, and I picked the Dell over them because you can expand the RAM to 8GB and it has a 500GB hard drive on the Dell.  The Steam 11 is stuck at 2GB and has a 32GB solid state drive.  Too, small, in my opinion, though you can throw in an SD card and double the storage space.  Also, I preferred the Dell's keyboard, felt less cheap, is full sized and has a 10 key.  I like how the battery is easily replaceable and there is easy access to update the RAM or hard drive.  Downsides?  The Dell feels big, not crazy big, but if all you want is a Starbuck's web surfer, a lighter, smaller 11 or 13 inch laptop would be a little easier to carry around. No DVD reader, but I rarely use them anymore.  No USB 3.0 ports, but as this price break, I can forgive.  And, as others, said, this is not a gaming computer, unless you like Nintendo emulators and that sort of thing.  I managed to run Minecraft and it was playable at lower settings, though the FPS would sometimes dip into the single digits.  I am not of fan of Windows 8.1, especially without a touchscreen...first world problems.  I am very happy to find this computer at under $200, would be less impressed at $250.

A bit surprised... This machine (and probably all Dell's going forward) does not have a Windows 8.1 Product Key sticker. Instead, according to Dell, the product key is embedded in one of the machine's chip sets. I intended to downgrade two of these cheapo laptops to W7 but after talking to Dell, that doesn't appear to be a viable option. Good news - you never have to remember or keep track of your product key, as long as you make a recovery disc using the Dell Factory Backup bootable recovery disc process. Bad news - Dell won't support the machine until its returned to W8, the drivers are apparently embedded as well, meaning there's strong likelihood there will be conflicts even if you install the W7 drivers, etc. The Dell rep I talked to says their low end machines are all produced like this now, but other processors won't have the problem. I really hate Windows 8 so I guess I'm stuck with two machines that can never be downgraded. Might go ahead and try to see what happens on the non-Celeron machine, but after spending 30 minutes with the (very helpful) Dell rep, I'm not holding my breath. Couple of other thoughts. This particular model has a Celeron processor. Dell rep said it definitely will give me problems if you downgrade the Celeron-based machines. Picture shows 3 USB ports. Mine has two. There's apparently a bay for a CD/DVD but it's covered by a blank. Not sure if an internal drive can be added, but I bought a LG DVD writer on Amazon for about twenty bucks (LG Electronics External Slim DVDRW). Must have a lower powered USB buss as the external DVD drive requires a double Type A USB cable (consuming both USB ports) on this machine, but not on my Dell XPS or wife's higher end Dell laptop. No ethernet port. Bought a USB 3.0 hub/ethernet adapter on Amazon for about fifteen bucks ([3*USB 3.0 + 1*Gigabit Ethernet Adapter] ZeroLemon 3 Ports USB 3.0 Bus-Powered Hub with RJ45 10/100/1000 Gigabit Ethernet Converter. The keyboard is not backlit - no surprise there, but it is comfortable and has good tactile response. Both machines came needing a BIOS upgrade. I'd recommend that. Since this machine is for guests and the other is for my garage, I'm ok with the performance. At the end of the day I probably should have spent the extra hundred bucks... But that's what you get these days for just under two-fifty. So, while it's cheap, it's not really a bargain...

Easily Removable Battery: Laptops eventually develop problems that can sometimes be resolved by removing the battery.

I bought my first Dell 3531 in August as we have three people in school and had only one laptop, so we needed another to cut down on the fighting among the kids.  I installed our Office 10 on it and runs without issue, no lagging at all. My 16 year old ended up taking over the machine and has had no complaints so far.

Basic set up for the system is very basic, starting with the Celeron dual core processor.  These Celeron units run cool enough that it does not need a system fan which cuts down on vibration and noise.  There is NO cd-rom on these machines.  If you need one, pick up a USB 2.0 external drive.  The memory is a 4gig Single Channel DDR3 1600MHz chip and can be upgraded very easily to an 8gig Single Channel DDR3 1600MHz which will improve performance (this can be done by taking the back compartment off of the machine, there are youtube videos how to do it).  The wireless card is a Dell Wireless 1506 and is also an upgrade option, but in this case you have to take off the keyboard to upgrade it (there is also a youtube video on how to do this as well).  From my understanding the Intel 7260 H/T Dual Band 2x2 adapter will work in the machine (first download drivers from intel and store them on the machine before installing, drivers are not native). I will be testing the dual band wireless adapter as soon as it gets here.  The hard drive is an SATA II - 500gb 5600 RPM drive.  It can be upgraded to a 'slim SSD', or slim solid state drive, which will also speed up the system performance, although this is only recommended for those who know about cloning drives, or feel comfortable reinstalling windows.  The memory and wireless card upgrades are both easy and will make an improvement to the system performance.

The first system purchased on 8/4 is still going strong and I just picked up a second one from the Dell doorbuster sale for $200 after taxes.

Update 12/15/2014 - the Intel 7260 H/T Dual Band 2x2 wireless network adapater works great, improves performance of the machine greatly as the stock card is basically a bottom of the barrel card.

Anyone who wants to boost performance quite easily should look into the wireless neetwork card (roughly $30) and the memory upgrade (roughtly $70).  That extra $100 spent will make the machine perform like a much more expensive device.

I have been using my husband's 10 inch touch screen "laptop" for months, and finally got sick of the kinks I was getting in my neck and shoulder from hunching over to type on the itty bitty keyboard. I spent about a week looking at reviews and checking out different laptops, but what made the difference for me was ultimately, the price. When this laptop dropped $30 to $219, I decided it was worth the shot. I'm glad I did!

I use the laptop for social networking, online schooling (which requires a ton of legal research), webcamming, and the general mom/student uses. I've been using it about a week now and haven't had a single problem with it. The battery lasts longer than any of the other iPads/laptops in my house. As a matter of fact, while I am almost constantly charging all of the other computers, I haven't had this one die on me yet. I charge it at night and whenever I'm not using it and haven't had a problem otherwise.

The size of the computer itself is awesome! It has a full keyboard, including a number keypad, and a large mouse pad that's simple to use. I also love that it is not a touchscreen, because when my 3 year old comes up trying to touch the screen, it's nice that it does not respond. It has 2 USB and 1 HDMI port, and no fan sound that I've been able to hear. I'm far from a computer whiz, but it definitely meets all of my needs!

Works yet Dirt Slow

(Updated) (Updated again) Let's start with answering the only question I had about this computer: "Can I add an internal optical drive inside the plastic spacer, or even maybe a second HDD with a caddy?". The answer is "No, you can not! There is no SATA connector behind the spacer".

On the other hand, it is very much upgrade-friendly. The minute I got it out of the box, I took out hard drive and cloned it onto SSD I have, so this machine runs with Crucial M500 SSD now. You can also upgrade to 8 Gb of RAM, but I wouldn't bother, really.

I am blown by the quality of the product. Screen, trackpad and build quality are exceptional for $220 that I paid for this machine. $220 is a sweet price for this, and I think it blows away any competition, but read on!

Case is plastic, but very pleasant to touch. Good keyboard, trackpad looks durable, screen is very decent, too. Not 180 degrees viewing angles, but very good anyway.

Pros:
- Upgrade-friendly! HDD and RAM are easily accessible, and service manual is easy to get
- Nice quiet keyboard
- Quality screen
- Good trackpad
- Quite snappy
- Build quality
- Light
- Quiet and cool (in fact, it's absolutely silent with SSD)

Cons:
- No optical drive (keep that in mind)
- Fingerprint magnet, but not too bad
- Trackpad buttons make relatively loud "click"
- You need to get rid of pre-installed antivirus, otherwise it's too slow (use standard Windows Defender instead)
- Only 2 USB ports, and they are USB 2.0
- I hate Dell trackpad driver! remember, FIRST thing you need to do is go into trackpad settings and disable one-finger gestures! Otherwise it's almost unusable.

But seriously, for sub-$250 laptop that is very good. I owned a Chromebook before, a few models, and this one beats them both in functionality, build quality and (some) price.

If you are looking at Chromebooks, look at this machine, too! It can run Skype and proper Windows applications, and easy to upgrade. HP Stream 11 and 13 may be decent alternatives, too, but if you are looking for classic black color, and classic big screen you can easily read, Dell is your choice.

Highly recommended.

Update 1: Make sure you install a driver for card reader from Dell website. Out of the box it has a wrong driver, and reads cards quite slowly. After updating driver, it's up to decent speeds!

Update 2: I am very, very pleased with the purchase! Completely silent and very fast with SSD! Copying photos from SD card - very quick! Editing and browsing in Google Picasa - amazingly quick. Plays 1080p without issues! And most surprisingly, even when CPU is 100% loaded, no noticeable degradation of performance, I don't know how they achieved this. Microsoft Office (Word, Excel) - very snappy.

Update 3: For a couple of weeks now, this has been my multimedia centre! Connected via HDMI to my HD TV, watching TV series on-line. No issues whatsoever! Snappy, battery lasts forever, smooth and pleasant playback. Seriously thinking about selling my multimedia PC now :)

So once again, here's what you need to do to get the most out of this machine:
- Uninstall McAffee software (enable Windows Defender instead)
- Disable 1-finger gestures for the touchpad (review all other touchpad settings, too)
- Get drivers for WiFi and card reader from Dell website, and install them
- Create a factory backup flash drive in Dell Backup and Restore, and..

So this was my first windows computer I have bought in a while. I was excited with the new version of windows that security was going to be less of an issue.  So after setting up all my software, uninstalling all the crap that Dell sticks on this machine ... I wanted to double check that the hard drive was encrypted, I had read that this is the default setting for Windows 8.1.  My main fear with a laptop is it gets stolen, and I want to make sure whoever steals it can't get at all the websites I use on daily basis.

Low and behold the drive isn't encrypted, so I look around for Bitlocker so I can turn it on.  Whoops, Bitlocker doesn't come with the version of windows that is on this computer.  So in 2014 and using Microsofts latest OS I cannot encrypt my hard drive.  Digging a little deeper I find that its quite easy to get past the password security that windows uses on startup, so my computer is basically completely vulnerable.

So in a state of disbelief I realize I will have to upgrade my version of windows for $100.  I click on the new Windows screens that are supposed to make this really straight forward and I get a blue screen that says "BUYING ONLINE IS NOT ACTIVE IN YOUR REGION, TRY GOING TO AN ELECTRONICS STORE".  For the record my region is Seattle, where Microsoft's HQ is located.  So I look around some more and find lots of forums talking about people that tried to upgrade and paid the money but couldn't make it work.

So I look into 3rd party disk encryption and after trying one of the most popular open source ones out the computer is now unbootable.  Since Dell provided no bootable disks with this computer  I have now taken this computer and tossed it into the garbage.  On one hand I wasted $250 and a lot of time with a horribly designed OS ... but on the other hand I got the reminder I needed to never buy a Microsoft product for the remainder of my life.  So I think net net, this was a win.

Are you looking for something as portable as a tablet, but more useful as computer? This laptop may be just what you need. However, keep in mind that this computer does not come with a DVD tray or Ethernet port. At first, I was planning to get a tablet to surf the web, but tablets are very expensive for the few functions they provide. Although this computer is not powerful, it doesn't need to be. If you want a powerful computer, then go BUILD your own desktop. High performance laptops are a big waste of money, x4 the price of a desktop and x0.5 the power. If you need computing power, then build a $600 desktop for gaming and other heavy processing tasks. Back to the topic, I find this computer light and comfortable to carry (for a size reference it will not fit into the laptop holder of the NorthFace Recon and will likely be a tight fit in 15in laptop compartments). The screen of the laptop has decent pixel density (max 1366x768). It's not as good as my desktop monitor's resolution (1920x1080), but you will get used to it in a week. The battery life is around 3 - 4 hours during actual use (word processing, surfing the web, ect). The advertised battery life is probably taken at the lowest brightness, with no applications running, and with WiFi turned off. This computer is for people who want a computer for mobile word processing and web surfing. I use this laptop for taking notes in college; it works extremely well. I felt bad seeing other people wasting money on $800- $1500 laptops, you can get this computer and a powerful desktop for that much. Feel free to ask about anything else that I forgot to mention.

I returned this Inspiron Latop today. The original reason I considered returning it was due to the lack of the responsiveness of the keyboard, however, I, like some other folks that bought this model, was frustrated with Windows 8. I will note that I have owned multiple Inspirons over the years both high end and low end and for the most part have been satisfied. I'm actually typing this review on an Inspiron N4110 that I picked up on sell at Best Buy about 3 years ago and have been satisfied with.

As I said, the main problem with this model is the keys just seem to have "clunky" feel. It seems to take more pressure to push them down than the keyboard I'm using now and I have noticed my typing speed is slower and I make more typos. As others have noted in their reviews of this item the cursor pad seems a bit sluggish and the buttons make an audible click that is distracting.

As noted in my original review I'm not familiar with Windows 8 having used Windows 7 for the past few years. That said, I found the transition to Windows 8 a bit difficult and the changes don't lend themselves to intuitive learning based on previous editions. Having all program and application icons, weather, email, etc. appear in random order of tiles of different sizes is just confusing and I much preferred the more organized tool bar that showed all programs and only popped up when you clicked it. I think this may have finally been the Windows straw that broke the camel's back (sorry for mixing my metaphors) and I think I am ready to make the leap to an Apple Mac now.

I must add that I was very impressed with Amazon's responsiveness to my returning this item. I ordered this product twice and had to return it both times which lead to a lot of frustration and wasted time.

Try 1
Product arrived just fine and I opened it up, started it up and it was working perfectly except for one tiny problem. 1 pixel. Yes one red pixel was stuck on the whole time. I tried a myriad of different strategies I found online to try to fix it and yet it wouldn't go away. So after about a day of different attempts and repeated failures I decided to return it.

Try 2
Computer comes on time. Works out of the box. Little sluggish as usual but tolerable and workable. Within a week the computer started having strange browser issues. The computer, despite having a working internet connection, wouldn't load webpages. Tried multiple browsers, same problem existed. The pages would just be in continual loading phase. Tried re-installing the wifi drivers to no avail. Tried installing windows updates, no help. Tried windows recovery to an earlier time, still nothing.

One lemon is a bad sign but a statistical inevitability. Two lemons in a row is a clear sign of crummy computers with poor construction and reliability.

Other Notes: Even after the first use of the computer it is notable that the computer is a bit slow, even right out of the box. Now if you're buying a computer for under $300 you should fully expect this, but be sure to be able to gauge your tolerance for it. Once a few programs are running and every time you click you have to wait several seconds before anything happens at all. If you try to watch full screen videos on YouTube the computer gets a bit overwhelmed and will lag fairly often. It can start to wear on you pretty quickly. For this reason I think I'm going to get at least an i3 processor next time around.
Also this computer comes with a bit of spyware/malware that should be removed right off the bat. All in all, more trouble than it's worth.

I depend on other consumers for their truthful and detailed experience so I don't have to go into trouble of having a product that is not adequate. As someone who has been in the technology field for 15+ years now, I'm always picky about hardware for myself. I was looking at this laptop for my wife and given that she doesn't use a computer all that often, I didn't want to break the bank for something that sits.

After getting this & going through all the setup for it, I would say that if I were shopping for me, I'd have bought this same laptop. Unless you're using this for hardcore gaming, this machine has plenty of horsepower for everyday use. If you want it that much faster, I'd just swap a SSD in place of the current HD to get the extra speed. Otherwise, this is fine.

I would recommend going through and uninstalling all the crap that PC manufacturers install these days, including the anti-virus software. McAfee slows things waaaay down and with this setup, you don't need that kind of hog. Once you uninstall it, Windows Defender is on and it will cover you just the same without using up more unnecessary resources.

Microsoft gives you SkyDrive space with a windows ID you can create during the setup of Win 8. You can add it to your iDevice as well, in order to sync your photos and everything between devices.

One major perk to this laptop is that it has a replaceable battery. Most low cost laptops I looked at did not, so when the battery had problems you were limited in just having a plugged in laptop, which cuts the usefulness of having a laptop to begin with.

There is no DVD drive, but that's also par for what current manufacturers are doing for laptops.

Overall, I'd say this is a great laptop for people who aren't looking to drop $500+ for a machine they won't use all that often. Also would be good for students, as it runs office & internet apps just fine.

The perks of the system are as follows:

1. Intuitive touch-pad functionality: The touch-pad can be difficult to work with, but with support for 4-finger macros with the included touch-pad software for multiple functions and macros. (Macros are shortcuts that can be toggled according to a configuration)

2.  Low power consumption. Windows 8.1 has showed the battery life at 12 hours and 36 minutes countless numbers of time after reducing the maximum CPU load to 50% of the offered capability with the back-light panel set to 20% - 29% and idle. Ubuntu 14.04 LTS has shown between 5 to 6 hours on a full charge. (I'm not certain if Ubuntu just uses more resources along-side Compiz compositing and the Unity environment)

3. The temperatures according to Almico Speedfan has showed between 29 Celsius and 50 Celsius depending on the load and the power settings. Ubuntu 14.04 LTS has pushed between 38 Celsius and 55 Celsius depending on the load and environment settings.

4. The laptop comes with an expansion for adding in an optical drive, and it can support up to 8GB with a single 1033 MHz DDR3 SODIMM module. (It initially comes with a single 4GB 1033 MHz DDR3 SODIMM module that consumes a low amount of voltage)

What I don't recommend you do with this laptop:

1. Stream HD videos through Adobe Flash Player. (I recommend HTML5 if you have the option)

2. Run Google Chrome with a few extensions. (It will eat up the processor's power and your RAM)

3. Turn it into a hackintosh project. (It can support a few modified systems, but you'll end up with a bad overall experience as performance will drop significantly, it will take a long time to boot into OS X, and it will also eat up more battery power lowering the overall battery life to 3 hours and 30 minutes to 2 hours depending on the CPU load)

For the price, this isn't a bad laptop. There's plenty of functionality with a surprisingly nice touch-pad and wireless network capabilities.

The laptop loses a star for the lack of an Ethernet port, it would have helped me quite a bit when installing Ubuntu 14.04 LTS and Niresh OS X 10.7.3.

I picked this up for $199 at Micro Center just because it was $199. It is not a world-beater of a computer and compromises have been made all over the place to keep the cost down on this, but it does work... Just know what you're getting into before you take the plunge. The appeal to me was that it had the same CPU as a Chromebook I was looking at, but with a full desktop OS, but now I realize that this CPU might not be sufficient to handle a full desktop OS, or at least not Windows 8.1.

Pros
It's $199.
-While I certainly wouldn't characterize the performance as "snappy," it is acceptable for a $199 computer.
-It has good battery life.
-It has a nice keyboard with a number pad.
-It's light for its size.
-It has reasonably easy access to the battery, memory and hard drive, should you decide to upgrade or need to replace.

Cons
-The screen has a narrow viewing angle--so narrow that I couldn't find an angle at which at least part of the screen wasn't washed out. This was the deal-breaker for me and is the reason why I'll be returning mine.
-1080p video (both streaming and local) is choppy to the point where I don't want to watch it, although I believe it only has 720 lines of resolution anyway. Content at 720p was borderlining on acceptable.
-The trackpad is okay for simple pointing and clicking, but multi-touch gestures are mostly unusable.
-The speakers are quiet and tinny.
-It's a fingerprint magnet...although I do like the look of the casing otherwise!

First of all, I am definitely not a PC person. I am a mac guy. I purchased this computer because I needed a cheap computer to run certain applications that could only run on windows, such as the windows version of Microsoft office that I am familiar with and use at work everyday. I had windows installed on my mac via boot camp, but I found it convenient to hop back and forth between operating systems, and furthermore, boot camp was wasting precious hard drive space on my mac. The solution was this computer. It was a very basic, no frills, work machine and suits my purposes perfectly. I have no need to run any high end games or photo editing software. I merely needed this computer to run Microsoft office, financial software, and basic web browsing. For $250, it has been a steal! To turn it into a desktop, I hooked it up to a usb hub, with usb mouse and keyboard and an external monitor with a hdmi to vga adapter, and was able to replicate a dual monitor setup similar to the one I have a work as well. If you do not need a speed machine, but have very basic computing needs, this PC will definitely do the trick!

(IMPORTANT NOTE) Do not be confused by the nomenclature for this process as it goes by many names; i.e. migrate, copy, transfer, etc. This is *NOT* my video but it is very helpful. I've also reposted the video on how to remove the Dell HD and install the SSD. Here is the link.

Last note: it does not matter which SSD you purchase, it will be up to each individuals preference (i.e. price, features, etc.). So if you do buy a SSD, make sure that:

1) The SSD is a 2.5" drive, SATA III
2) Check to see if it comes with "cloning" (migration, transfer...) software.
3) If it does not, there are several other cloning software programs available online that are free to download. But I wouldn't recommend this route if this is your first drive swap.
4) Make sure you get a USB to SATA cable. This is the one I purchased. Buy it, use it, keep it or return it after your done. Your preference but you will need this.

Also, here are some pros and cons after owning the laptop for 3 months.

PROS:
-High price-value ratio, decent hardware components and performance for the price
-Extremely light weight and very thin
-Easy to upgrade components, you can do this rather economically to keep the overall costs down
-Full 10 key number pad and smooth key operation

-Great for medium-heavy work loads, i.e. running multiple programs, playing music or videos, etc.
-Solid construction, mine travels with me in my backpack and it takes a beating, haven't had any issues

CONS:
-Processor could be faster, however I mention below on how to increase the CPU's performance
-Lack of RAM. The 4GB RAM is quite slow but I describe my experience below after upgrading the RAM to 8GB
-Hard drive has plenty of storage but it's also slow. See below for SSD upgrade and comparison
-With the factory components, the laptop struggles with heavy flash websites. You can alleviate this issue by upgrading the hard drive and RAM

***UPDATE 10/24/14 - Putting this at the top since some have asked for instructions on how to replace the hard drive and RAM. Here are two (2) youtube videos (not mine) that will walk you through the process. NOTE: Pay close attention and follow his exact removal and re-install process of the cover on the underside of the laptop, otherwise you will break the plastic tabs.

Hard Drive removal and installing SSD
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Up5uGX1Bf4g

Upgrading RAM
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24kPq-xzwHc

REVIEW:

Great budget laptop, especially for students. Keep in mind the price reflects the product.

Before deciding to move on to other brands, consider that there are many consumers who purchase laptops without possessing any rudimentary knowledge about computer software and components. Let alone there are buyers who show lack of consumer aptitude by writing comments like "thought it came with a optical drive, 1 star."

So, quickly I'll highlight on a few things you can do to noticeably improve the performance of this laptop.

-First, replace the HDD with a SSD. You will experience an immediate performance boost. You'll need a USB to SATA cable to clone the drive. It is very, very easy and basic. Samsung offers a great software to assist you in this process. Here is the drive I purchased.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E3W15P0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Here is the cable.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0057UAB2K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

-Second, uninstall McAfee as it ties up many of your systems resources. Microsoft Defender comes pre-loaded, just turn this on. Also, uninstall all the Microsoft apps you do not use. Most of these run in the background tying up CPU resources.

-Third, unlock the CPU's parked cores as this will allow the processor to operate at it's highest output. To do this, follow these directory series. Control Panel\System and Security\Power Options\Edit Plan Settings. Then go to Advanced Power Settings. A new window opens, then scroll down to Processor Power Management and click to expand. You will see Minimum Processor State, click to expand. The default setting is 5%. Increase to 100%. You will notice that the Maximum Processor State is already at 100%. Apply the changes. Now you have a processor running at it's maximum performance capacity. You should see a overall noticeable performance increase in all areas.

-Fourth, make sure you have the Power Saver mode OFF. This mode tells the CPU and other components to run at a minimum state, hindering performance.

-Fifth, if you are comfortable with removing programs both in the control panel and in the registry, then remove all the unnecessary Dell software. You can use CCleaner to assist you.

-Sixth, using CCleaner, go to the start-up programs which run in the background. Turn off all the programs and automatic updates that you won't use.

I've seen tablets with more ports and expandabililty than this "laptop". It's not worth $249.99. I'd say it's worth about $200 at best. Don't pay more. My main reason for purchasing is the price and I desperately needed a new laptop but I didn't want to spend like $550 bucks on the laptop I wanted. However, I would have spent money elsewhere if I knew a feature on the product I bought sounded God awful.

Aside from that, I am pleased with the keyboard. It is the only thing that saves it. I like the number pad feature and am happy with how my fingers glissfully slide across the keys. I do NOT like how the caps key lights up but the number lock key does not. There isn't either a feature on the screen, that I can see so far, which details the number feature is engaged.

With all the junk on that screen, I missed the 'desktop' application.

The computer feels fairly sturdy. I like its thinness, another plus quality; although the plastic surrounding the mouse pad and the mouse pad buttons is cheap, everything else seems of quality.

You get what you pay for. It's arguably worth the money however the mouse pad is pretty atrocious. I'm surprised how cheap it really is. This laptop is amazing! Despite the fact that there's no optical drive, everything is perfect. The screen resolution is crystal clear, the speakers are amazing, and the track pad is easy to use. The home page/startup is easy to navigate which is the one thing I was mainly concerned about. Internet is fast and reliable, battery life lasts a long time. I love this laptop!

Windows requires you to fill in some information right off the bat before you actually use this laptop. I could not connect to my network with this laptop during the first two or three tries. That was my first warning that this laptop wasn't right.

I should have guessed that something would be wrong, given that Amazon shipped the laptop along with a printer in a gigantic box that was entirely too big with two sheets of brown paper and one flimsy strip of tape along the top that was already half ripped open.

I have consistently had issues with this laptop randomly dropping off the network since I finally got it connected the first time.  My iPhone has not had any issues with the network and my old laptop running Ubuntu occasionally has issues with the network. Oddly the Ubuntu laptop and this Dell laptop never fall off the network at the same time. I have a wireless router acting as a repeater about fifteen feet behind me.

I called Dell and the first gentleman told me that it sounded like a hardware issue and that I should probably just ship this laptop back to Amazon. The second gentleman wanted to take over the laptop remotely and do who knows what kind of troubleshooting. He spend two minutes trying to tell me where I should go to check something, which was two minutes too much since I was already on the screen I needed to be. He just automatically assumed I was a moron. I can't say I'm impressed with Dell's customer support and ultimately that may be why I'll never buy another Dell.

I have had great difficulty rousing this laptop out of "sleep." The screen will flash from black to white, then back to black again when I tap different keys or the power button. Occasionally I can see the login screen, but then the screen goes back to black.

Windows 8 is just as bad as everyone's told you unless you are very much connected to Microsoft's offerings like Hotmail. It has a neat look, but it's a huge change from previous Windows versions. Classic Shell does bring back that old Start button you knew and loved, so I suggest installing that along with Google Chrome and Adblock Plus as soon as you get a laptop running Windows 8. This laptop does have a matte almost black plastic case that does feel very, very cheap and shows fingerprints like crazy. It's big, it's clunky and it doesn't seem like it would take much of a beating if it accidentally slipped out of your hands. It's a cheap laptop, so you are getting what you paid for. One thing I really hate is the targeted advertising you get while using this computer. Dell and McAfee popups selling services while I try to use the laptop are very, very annoying. I understand this is a cheap laptop, and perhaps part of that reason is because McAfee paid Dell to use the latter's captive audience. It's akin to seeing ads on a website- you're there for the content, but you can't escape the intrusive, annoying ads on the page you're trying to read. This laptop was not bought so that we could be advertised to, so if this is how laptops are these days, count me out.

If an item says it has certain features, those should work. I am sending this laptop back today. I'm not happy with Amazon's shoddy shipping (no signature required to receive the package to boot!) and the potentially defective hardware on this laptop. This should work right out of the box and it doesn't. I really don't have an infinite amount of time to play around and troubleshoot this laptop's issues. Lemons happen and I know that. Maybe this laptop worked before Amazon shipped it out. If you receive this laptop and the packaging looks inadequate and/or beat up, just have UPS/Fed Ex return it back to Amazon. It's not worth your hassle.

Updated: Turns out power savings mode kills this laptop and makes it unworkable.  Thank you for the advice. I received this laptop 2 days ago and I'm shipping it back.  After reading all the reviews, I thought it would meet all my needs.  I'm not a heavy laptop user and only need a functional laptop for school.  I was going to use this laptop for lectures, taking notes, going through power point slides, and watching youtube videos.

The first sign of trouble came when I noticed there was a lag time for what I was typing and what was appearing on the screen.  For a laptop that just came right out of the box, this was a really bad sign.  Projecting a couple months when I've actually put programs onto this laptop, I can't imagine how much slower it might be.

The second sign of trouble came when I tried to load multiple pages at once.  Either this computer is not powerful enough to perform this function or I received a lemon.  If I tried to load 2 pages at once, the first page I tried to load would stop loading.

The third sign of trouble came when I tried watching a youtube video.  The video was laggy and there was this annoying buzzing sound that would come from the video's audio due to the lag.  It was like a static sound.  This was especially noticeable when I tried to look through my email as the video was running or go to a different tab.  The video would freeze up more and create more of that annoying static sound.  This was the final deal breaker for me as I need to be able to watch lectures for school while running other programs like Power Point or Microsoft Word to take notes.  If this computer can't even handle a simple youtube video while I try to check emails, I can't imagine how it would function while I have other programs running.

I tried talking to dell tech support about these issues of sound quality and the slow performance but they weren't able to help.  I'm sending this laptop back now.  I'm not sure how other people gave this thing such a high review.  Either I received a lemon or other users are happy using only 1 program at a time or 1 webpage at a time for this laptop.

I tried watching a hulu video today without any other programs running and even the hulu video stops every couple of seconds.  This isn't due to my wireless as my other computers don't have this issue at home.

Word of Warning: I would stay clear of this laptop and spend more money to get a better product. I have to ship this back now and will probably occur a restocking fee along with a shipping fee.

This laptop is pretty good for the price. I got it for $249 ($260ish after taxes). It's great for what it is! I see other reviews freaking out because there's not disk drive. Yes, it's stated right there there is none. Read better. Anyway, this has a decent amount of RAM. Windows 8.1 isn't nearly as bad as 8, if you install Start8 you can get your start bar back too. I also make it so the desktop shows and not the weird menu that 8 and 8.1 has. The graphics card isn't too bad for it being an integrated one. I can run the Sims 3 (all expansions too) with the graphics set to the lowest quality, no lag. Minecraft runs great, and so do games like Fallout 3 and NV if you turn the graphics all the way down. Processor speed is great too. For what I do with a computer/laptop this is the best for the prices. Webcam is decent too! I actually like the missing disk drive. I haven't used CD's in years. You can always get a USB CD/DVD drive or just make a bootable flash/usb stick like I normally do.

This is a fully functional laptop at under $300.00.  The price is realized since there is no optical drive, touch screen, Bluetooth or wired Ethernet, but at this price that's OK.  You can use an external drive and WiFi for your connection needs.

Even with the plastic feel it's been quite durable and easy to care for with storage in a case when not in use.  I also like to use a trackball instead of mouse or touch-pad, but the touch-pad is OK if you decide not go that route.  It is a fully functional system with a bright easy to read screen, that is perfect for web browsing, checking email, watching movies download to the hard drive and has fired right up even after sitting in my hot car for most of the day.

It is a bit sluggish with high performance software and that's the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5.  Overall, a really great system and one that will serve you well.  I suggest this a starter system for middle school age children that have the discipline to care for such items but don't need the high power and extras of a more expensive system.

I was anxious and excited to receive my new Dell since I require a portable computer for school. I found this model and the specs seemed adequate for my needs. Unfortunately I was completely wrong. Right out of the box it was the slowest computer I've handled in what must be years! The simplest tasks, whether it be open Microsoft Word or Internet Explorer would clock at about a minute. A full minute to just open the page to make a web search is impractical. Let alone actually make the search! I was able to bring up a speed test and use another fast computer on my home wifi and the other computer blazed and the speed test said I was getting 25 Mbps so there was no problem with wifi! Pros: The screen is huge and nice for the price point. Battery is great too.

Cons: Everything else. I really mean it when I say SLOW. It's sad that a new product put into consumers hands can't handle the included operating system (Windows 8.1) and if it struggles just to open the Microsoft Office Suite I don't see how this machine could be worth anyone's time, unfortunately.

**Again, please don't let the low price fool you. You are paying for a slow, low-end laptop which struggles on the most basic tasks.

My wife and I were looking for notebooks for our kids (9 and 11 yrs old). DELL had a sale for $200.00 for this model, and we could not pass up the opportunity. All in all, this is an excellent laptop for kids or very basic laptop for a family.

PROS:
1. CHIP: Intel Celeron (dual core). This is a latest Celeron chip (N2830, Bay Trail - M) you will have. Being a dual core can handle most of the demands easily. Because it is a Bay Trail chip, it is quiet and not heavy on your resources. It is so quiet, you hardly hear the fan at all. So for your Web browsing, emails, YouTube viewing, MS Office, some gaming, and every day chores, this is a great basic laptop.
2. BUILD. The black matte finish is not fancy but functional. Simple but sturdy. The keyboard has no flex, and comes with chiclet keyboard that is well designed and generously spaced. The screen is bright and resolution is normal for this price range.
3. PRICE. Price differs from store to store, but if you get it in right time, you might get it for around $200.00. Even $250 is a good price. To give you a comparison: various Chromebooks are priced in this range but with less functions and memories. Additionally, you CANNOT install any Windows programs (such as, MS Office, etc), so while Chromebooks have their proper place, for those who need basic laptop for general use, this laptop might be a better fit in this price range.
4. OS. Windows 8.1 is far, far better than Windows 8.0. If you already have 8.0, then you should update/upgrade it to 8.1. I love using it, and my kids love the tiles. PLUS, I love 8.1's Family Safety feature. I can control how much my kids can be on the computer and what days. Additionally you can also filter what kind of web they are browsing. MS also sends you (the parent) weekly report on the kids use of the computer. Love this feature! Easy to set up and monitor.

CONS:
1. No optical Drive (DVD/CD). But nowadays, this is not really needed anymore. But for those who need it, you might have to consider other models.
2. No Bluetooth. The box says, "Bluetooth" but this is misprint. This model does NOT have Bluetooth.
3. Only 2 USB (2.0) ports. I was hoping that it had another USB port.

Despite the cons, considering its price, this is an excellent entry laptop for kids and those who just want sturdy, dependable laptop for every day general use. Highly, highly recommended!

It's got the new N2830 Baytrail processor. It's cheap, it's fast enough, and most importantly (to me) it's fanless. The marketing didn't even mention this. I couldn't even find out whether it had a fan or not without reading another amazon review (thank you reviewer).

There are a couple similar windows laptops being released by competing brands also with the N2830 processor. Toshiba's version only has 2GB memory. The Asus version looks great, but it's only 3 cell instead of the 4 on this one, and it's not even out yet.

Asus also has a line of chromebooks that have this exact same processor, the C200, and C300s. These are smaller and more portable, but have small hard drives and Chrome OS, which can be hard to develop on.

I ran windows once, and got the licence using the magical jelly bean keyfinder, and then quickly erased it, disabled uefi and installed linux mint xfce. Everything is going good. I get around 7000 score on octane benchmark. This is a very good score for a fanless. Dell's Venue tablets score in the 4000s. Samsungs fanless chromebook 2 gets around 6000 i believe. Basically I'm not aware of any fanless computer getting comparable performance that didn't have this processor. That said, your basic intel i3 cpu with a fan will get at least double this score. So while it's good for fanless, you get at least double the performance and likely more if you have a better cpu with a fan. You will not be able to play any serious games. I couldn't even get a solid 60fps playing counter-strike 1.6. I could play super meat boy without lag at 60fps. Fez and Bastion I was getting around 30 fps on average and dipping below.

If fanless cpu's are important to you, you should note that intel is planning on releasing a cpu line named Broadwell during the winter which will also have fanless variants and should be much more powerful. So It may be better to wait for these.

One thing to note is that the design has very obviously been recycled. There's a panel over where a cd drive would have been, and there's no fan in the area that there would have been. It's as though as soon as Dell got their hands on the new Processor they just whipped this together. And that's okay. Because I care more about getting this processor faster than getting a design tailored to this laptops capabilities.

Keyboard is fine. Trackpad is nice and big and not sticky. Mouse clicks are brittle but loud. Layout is a little wonky. I prefer how ASUS laysout their keys with the page up and downs going down the side.

Make sure you only pay $250 for this laptop. The price is what makes this amazing. The default payment option when I bought this laptop on amazon was $300 dollars. Don't fall for it!. Better yet just buy it directly from Dell.
